questions.text: The following phenomenon not be observed in?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrheae

questions.text: Which of the following stains are used to visualize the specific fibers present in the following cartilage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Verhoeff's stain

 

The image shows elastic cartilage, identified by the presence of densely packed chondrocytes and a matrix containing elastic fibers. Verhoeff’s stain is specifically used to visualize elastic fibers, turning them black and allowing for detailed study of their distribution in tissues like elastic cartilage.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Bielchowsky stain: Used for nerve fibers.

 

 

Option C. GMS silver stain: Used for fungi.

 

 

Option D. Alcian Blue stain: Used for acidic mucopolysaccharides, not specifically elastic fibers.

questions.text: Identify the staining method for a tissue biopsy of the painless ulcer shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levaditi's method 

 

  • The clinical image shows a painless genital ulcer, which is the primary chancre of syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • T. pallidum is a spirochete → very thin, spiral-shaped bacterium, not visible on routine Gram stain.
  • Special stains and techniques are required:

 

Levaditi's method

 

  • A silver impregnation stain.
  • Commonly used to demonstrate spirochetes (eg, Treponema pallidum) in tissue sections of EXUDATE SMEAR.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fontana’s method: Another silver impregnation method, used to demonstrate spirochetes as well, but less commonly used for T. pallidum in biopsy tissue.

 

 

Option C. Castaneda’s method:

 

  • Culture method used for Brucella (blood culture bottles with biphasic medium).
  • Not related to spirochetes.

 

 

Option D. Albert’s method: Used to demonstrate metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby was brought with history of recurrent infections in the past 4 months. On examination white patches were present in oral mucosa which could be scraped easily. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Tonsils are present

questions.text: Which of the following is a pigment-producing species of mycobacteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) M. scrofulaceum 

 

  • Some non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) produce pigments (carotenoid-like), and classification is based on Runyon’s groups:

 

Pigment-producing groups:

 

  • Photochromogens (Group I): Produce pigment only on exposure to light.
    • Examples: M. kansasii, M. marinum.
  • Scotochromogens (Group II): Produce pigment even in the dark.
    • Examples: M. scrofulaceum, M. gordonae.

 

Nonchromogens (Group III): Do not produce pigment.

 

  • Examples: M. avium-intracellulare complex, M. ulcerans, M. xenopi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. M. ulcerans:

 

  • Causes Buruli ulcer.
  • Nonchromogen → does not produce pigment.

 

Option C. M. avium-intracellulare complex (MAC):

 

  • Causes disseminated disease in AIDS patients.
  • Nonchromogen.

 

Option D. M. xenopi: 

 

  • Causes pulmonary disease.
  • Nonchromogen.

questions.text: A 25-year-old HIV/AIDS man presents with fever, headache, photophobia and neck rigidity since the last 2 days. What is the empirical therapy of choice for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Cefepime + Vancomycin + Ampicillin

questions.text: Which of the following mediators of inflammation is an example of a C-X-C chemokine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IL-8

 

IL-8 is a C-X-C chemokine that primarily attracts neutrophils to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Lipoxin LXA-4: A lipid mediator that resolves inflammation, not a chemokine.

 

Option C. Lymphotactin: A C chemokine, attracts lymphocytes, not neutrophils.

 

Option D. Fractalkine: A CX3C chemokine, involved in leukocyte adhesion and migration.

questions.text:
Identify the microaerophilic bacteria from the list: 

 

  1. Positive CLO test. 
  2. Gram-negative bacilli implicated in GBS
  3. Gram-negative curved bacilli with 'fish-in-stream' appearance 
  4. Bacteria showing 'mercury drop' colonies. 
  5. LJ medium showing ruff, buff, tough colonies.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2   

 

Microaerophilic Bacteria:

 

  • Microaerophiles are organisms that require oxygen for survival, but at a lower concentration (5–10%) than atmospheric levels (21%).
  • Too much oxygen is toxic for them (due to lack of complete detoxifying enzymes like catalase, superoxide dismutase).
  • They often colonize environments with reduced oxygen tension, e.g. GI tract, genital tract.

 

1. Positive CLO test → Helicobacter pylori:

 

  • CLO = Campylobacter-like organism test, a rapid urease test.
  • H. pylori is a curved, Gram-negative bacillus, strongly urease positive.
  • Requires microaerophilic conditions (5% O₂, 10% CO₂, 85% N₂).
  • Clinical association → Peptic ulcers, gastritis, gastric carcinoma.

 

2. Gram-negative bacilli implicated in GBS → Campylobacter jejuni:

 

  • Leading cause of bacterial gastroenteritis (GBS = Guillain-Barré Syndrome, post-infectious complication).
  • Curved, comma-shaped, motile, Gram-negative bacilli.
  • Requires microaerophilic atmosphere and grows best at 42°C.
  • Classic “gull-wing” appearance on microscopy.

 

Other statements:

 

3. Gram-negative curved bacilli with "fish-in-stream" appearance → Vibrio cholerae:

 

  • Facultative anaerobe, not microaerophilic.
  • “Fish-in-stream” motility seen in hanging drop prep.
  • Causes cholera with rice-water stools.

 

4. Bacteria showing “mercury drop” colonies → Bordetella pertussis:

 

  • Small, Gram-negative coccobacillus.
  • Colonies on Bordet-Gengou agar resemble mercury drops.
  • Strict aerobe, not microaerophilic.

 

5. LJ medium showing “rough, buff, tough” colonies → Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

 

  • Obligate aerobe, grows best in high O₂ tension.
  • Not microaerophilic.

choices.text: Resistant to El Tor phage V
Not susceptible to group IV phage

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of EI Tor vibrio?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Resistant to El Tor phage V   

 

The El Tor biotype of Vibrio cholerae O1 has distinct laboratory characteristics compared to the classical biotype. 

 

El Tor phage V → El Tor strains are susceptible, not resistant 

 

  • Classical strains are resistant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intrinsic resistance to polymyxin B: Classical strains are sensitive.

 

Option C. Voges-Proskauer test positive: Classical strains are negative.

 

Option  D. Not susceptible to group IV phage: Classical strains are lysed by group IV cholera phage.

 

Summary Table: Classical vs El Tor Biotype

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with difficulty swallowing, hydrophobia, and aerophobia after being bitten by a bat. He develops spasms, agitation, and coma, eventually succumbing to respiratory failure. Histopathological examination of his brain is shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the viral genome of the pathogen?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Single-stranded RNA, negative-sense, enveloped

questions.text: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporangiophore

 

Sporangiophore is not a spore but a specialized hyphal stalk that bears asexual spores (sporangiospores).Hence, it is not a sexual spore

 

Sexual spores are formed after fusion of nuclei (karyogamy + meiosis) in fungi.

 

 

  • Main sexual spores include:
    1. Zygospore → formed by fusion of two similar gametangia (Zygomycetes).
    2. Ascospore → formed inside an ascus (Ascomycetes).
    3. Basidiospore → formed on basidium (Basidiomycetes).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zygospore: True sexual spore, seen in Zygomycetes (Rhizopus, Mucor).

 

Option C. Basidiospore: Sexual spore produced externally on a basidium, seen in mushrooms, smuts, rusts.

 

Option D. Ascospore: Sexual spore produced inside an ascus, typical of Ascomycetes (Saccharomyces, Aspergillus).

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes with complaints of intermittent bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks after consuming street food during his travel. He is febrile and has RUQ tenderness. Which of the following is the infective form of the likely protozoan causing this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mature quadrinucleate cyst   

 

  • The case:
    • Bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks, history of street food consumption → suggests amoebic dysentery.
    • Right upper quadrant tenderness → points to amoebic liver abscess (complication of Entamoeba histolytica).
  • Life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica:
    • Infective form → Mature quadrinucleate cyst (4 nuclei).
    • Acquired through fecal–oral route, contaminated food or water.
    • Cyst survives stomach acid → excystation in small intestine → releases trophozoites → invade colon (causing dysentery) or spread to liver (abscess).
    • Trophozoite → diagnostic stage (in stool, in tissues), but not infective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trophozoite:

 

  • Motile, invasive form found in tissues and fresh stool.
  • Responsible for clinical disease (ulceration, abscess).
  • Not infective, as it cannot survive gastric acidity.

 

Option C. Metacyclic trophozoite:

 

  • Seen in Trypanosoma (not Entamoeba).
  • Infective stage of trypanosomes transmitted by vectors (eg, tsetse fly).

 

Option D. Precyst:

 

  • Transitional stage before cyst formation.
  • Not infective; must mature into quadrinucleate cyst.

questions.solution: Ans. A) IgG is used to diagnose fetal infection

questions.text: Which of the following bones violates ‘The secondary ossification center that appears first, fuses last’ law?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibula 

 

There is a general rule in skeletal development:
“The secondary ossification center that appears first is the one that fuses last.”

 

Fibula: The secondary center at the distal end appears before the proximal one, but it fuses earlier. This is the classic exception to the law
This helps in determining growth patterns and forensic age estimation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radius: Distal end ossifies first and fuses last → follows the rule.

 

Option C. Ulna: Distal end ossifies first and fuses last → follows the rule.

 

Option D. Sternum: Sternebrae ossify and fuse late, generally following the rule.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events of pre-embryonic development in order, from the earlier stage to the later stage:

 

  1. Cavitation
  2. Compaction
  3. Implantation
  4. Cleavage
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 - 2 - 1 - 3

 

The correct chronological order for these events in pre-embryonic development is:

 

  • Cleavage (4)
    • Immediately after fertilization, the zygote undergoes rapid mitotic divisions.
    • Results in blastomeres without increasing the overall size of the embryo.
  • Compaction (2)
    • At around the 8-cell stage, blastomeres tightly adhere to each other via tight junctions.
    • This forms the morula.
  • Cavitation (1)
    • Fluid begins to accumulate inside the morula, creating the blastocoel.
    • The structure is now called a blastocyst.
  • Implantation (3): The blastocyst embeds itself into the endometrium (around day 6–7).

questions.solution: Ans. D) Hypoglossal

questions.solution: Ans. B) Recurrent artery of Heubner

questions.text: Which of the following descending tracts in the spinal cord remains uncrossed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vestibulospinal tract 

 

  • Origin: Vestibular nuclei in medulla and pons.
  • Remains largely uncrossed.
  • Controls extensor tone and maintains balance/posture.
  • Uncrossed → correct answer.

 

Most descending motor tracts in the spinal cord cross (decussate) at some point, but a few remain uncrossed to ensure bilateral control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tectospinal tract:

 

  • Origin: Superior colliculus of midbrain.
  • Crosses immediately in the dorsal tegmental decussation.
  • Controls reflex head movements to visual/auditory stimuli.
  • Crossed.

 

Option B. Rubrospinal tract:

 

  • Origin: Red nucleus of midbrain.
  • Crosses almost immediately in the ventral tegmental decussation.
  • Facilitates flexor muscles.
  • Crossed.

 

Option D. Pyramidal tract (corticospinal tract):

 

  • Origin: Motor cortex.
  • About 80–90% cross at the pyramidal decussation (lateral corticospinal tract).
  • Remaining 10–20% stay uncrossed as anterior corticospinal tract but eventually cross near the level of termination.

 

Thus, not considered completely uncrossed.

questions.text: All of the following tracts pass through inferior cerebellar peduncle except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Anterior spinocerebellar

questions.text: Which of the following branches of internal Carotid artery are given off in the cervical region?
questions.solution: Ans. D) None of the above

questions.solution: Ans. A) Subclavian triangle

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of tobacco chewing presented with a non-healing ulcer over the tip of the tongue. Biopsy revealed squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following would be the sentinel lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Submental lymph nodes

 

The lymphatic drainage of the tongue is highly site-specific and clinically important in cases of carcinoma.

 

  • Tip of the tongue → drains first into the submental lymph nodes (sentinel nodes).
  • Lateral anterior 2/3 of tongue → drains mainly into submandibular lymph nodes.
  • Medial anterior 2/3 of tongue → drains bilaterally into deep cervical lymph nodes, especially jugulo-omohyoid.
  • Posterior 1/3 of tongue → drains directly into jugulo-digastric (upper deep cervical) nodes.

 

Thus, in carcinoma at the tip of tongue, the submental nodes are the sentinel lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle causes opening of laryngeal inlet?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroepiglotticus

 

The laryngeal inlet (aditus laryngis) is the opening between the pharynx and the larynx. Its size is regulated by small intrinsic laryngeal muscles.

 

Thyro-epiglotticus:

 

  • A small muscle derived from the thyroarytenoid.
  • Function: widens the laryngeal inlet by depressing the epiglottis and dilating the vestibule.
  • Hence, it is responsible for opening of the laryngeal inlet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocalis:

 

  • A part of thyroarytenoid muscle.
  • Adjusts tension of the vocal cords for fine-tuning of voice.
  • Does not act on the laryngeal inlet.

 

Option C. Cricoarytenoid:

 

  • Refers generally to posterior and lateral cricoarytenoid muscles.
  • Posterior cricoarytenoid: abducts vocal cords (only muscle that opens the rima glottidis, not the laryngeal inlet).
  • Lateral cricoarytenoid: adducts vocal cords.
  • Neither directly opens the inlet.

 

Option D. Thyroarytenoid:

 

  • Relaxes vocal cords and narrows the laryngeal inlet.
  • Opposite of inlet opening.
